Recent changes to dockerSkeleton runtime now allows for better support for bash actions.
Using `--native` with a simple script is the recommend way for bash actions.

For example:

bash.sh reads  a line from \<STDIN\>
```
$ cat bash.sh
#!/bin/bash
read ARGS
A=`echo "$ARGS" | jq '."a"'`
B=`echo "$ARGS" | jq '."b"'`
C=`echo "$ARGS" | jq '."c"[0]'`
RES=$(($B + $C))
echo A is $A
echo "{ \"result\": \"$RES\" }"
```
```
wsk action update bash bash.sh --native
```
```
ok: updated action bash
```

```
wsk action invoke bash -p a A -p b 123 -p c '[1,2,3]' -r
```
```json
{
    "result": 124
}
```
```
wsk activation logs --last --strip
```
```
A is "A"
```

docs will update to reflect this new usage.

For whom ever wants to contribute this, this is the recommended approach.

### 1. Support both ubuntu14 and ubuntu16
Make the following scripts work out of the box on unbuntu14 or unbunt16.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/tree/master/tools/ubuntu-setup/
```
tools/ubuntu-setup/ansible.sh
tools/ubuntu-setup/docker.sh
tools/ubuntu-setup/java8.sh
tools/ubuntu-setup/misc.sh
tools/ubuntu-setup/pip.sh
tools/ubuntu-setup/scala.sh
```
### 2. Version of docker engine 1.12
Currently we only support docker 1.12
Update `tools/ubuntu-setup/docker.sh`  that by default install docker 1.12 on both (ubuntu14/16), for those that want to experiment on their own, allow via environment variable to override this and instead use latest version of docker.

### 3. Have a way to test it
I think there could be 2 options:
1. Setup Travis to run in matrix running in parallel ubunt14 and ubunt16
2. Update Vagrant deployment to use ubunt16
Fix is here https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3262

As per of setup one needs to [accept terms of service][1] via 

```
buildScan {
    termsOfServiceUrl = 'https://gradle.com/legal/terms-of-service'
    termsOfServiceAgree = 'yes'
    publishAlwaysIf(System.getenv('CI') != null)
}
```
So has some legal implication. Checking the usage in Apache project it appears that [Groovy project has this configured][2] so it should be ok to use

[1]: https://docs.gradle.com/build-scan-plugin/#accept_the_scans_gradle_com_terms_of_service
[2]: https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/270709706102e4efef5a59da0f185f48436a8402/build.gradle#L54

We should rather exclude `build` folders entirely. They are meant for generated artifacts.

@chetanmeh Given that we are not releasing all repos, as not all are considered as part of the serverless platform (version sensitive/tied), are optional tooling, represent in-development deployment options, etc., etc.  I think the approach taken in incubator-openwhisk-release (i.e., using a JSON config file) and our aggregator project, to not only drive the repos. that we have agreed to release as a group, but capture the overall commit snapshot is a good one.  

Again, the repos we are considering part of the essential platform release are listed on the CWIKI:  https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/OPENWHISK/GitHub+Repository+Status

Clearly, we will not release the website (.org), utilties, external-resources, etc. ever...

Where I believe we will be following precedence set in other projects (like Spark) that have large #s of repos. of add-ons, plug-ins, language alts., etc. that are considered to be released at a different pace/cadence based upon their maturity and contribution levels.  (e.g., https://spark.apache.org/third-party-projects.html). Over time I believe we as a community will decide how to handle the ecosystem of repos. (now 44 and counting) and which should be part of (and ready for based upon maturity) the project release.
@chetanmeh @houshengbo in fact, I was wondering why this issue was not opened in incubator-openwhisk-release?
The way I read the issue this is only about developer convenience in checking out the code (from the many OW repos). Do you see an impact on releases?
Apache wise this is OK, and it’s not a hard dependency to the main functionality of the core componets

that is all i was suggesting.

+1 I've had the same experience and find working across so many repos increasingly painful. Some changes too a lot more than one repo (eg an API change might affect runtime SDKs and the CLIs, or a runtime change will touch all the runtime repos). If there's a way to construct a mega repo conveniently for the purpose of full stack development, I'm all for it. I think this is mostly orthogonal to the release process which is more for consumption rather than development.

```
> cat .git/hooks/pre-commit
#!/usr/bin/env bash

set -e

# format all scala soruce
echo "formatting scala source"
$OPENWHISK_HOME/tools/git/pre-commit-scalafmt-native.sh

# scan all other files for conformance
python $OPENWHISK_HOME/../incubator-openwhisk-utilities/scancode/scanCode.py .
```
Opened #3317 for that

@mhenke1 can you double-check please?
@upgle Is there a possibility to move this check inside the `MetricEmitter`? More importantly: What's the behavior of this if you don't have Kamon setup? Any error logs?

@markusthoemmes 
yes it is possible to move inside the MetricEmitter. 
I modified the relevant code again.

Kamon always starts, regardless of `metrics_kamon: true` option, so it tries to send the meaningless metric without proper setting. It should be checked always `TransactionId.metricsKamon` is true.
- Controller [code](https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/a2d978108a97a36ad063ceb61dad63419392f076/core/controller/src/main/scala/whisk/core/controller/Controller.scala#L186)
- Invoker [code](https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/d7e59b5549525bbe68c1a0c8b8b28db91844b2d9/core/invoker/src/main/scala/whisk/core/invoker/Invoker.scala#L73)

Also, an error occurred in our custom kamon-backend (it is not a statsd backend), because it tries to send metric without proper setting though `metrics_kamon` configuration is `false`.

Anyone with write access to the repo can enable this on Travis settings 
I will enable to run daily only there have not being a build in the last 24 hours that way we don’t abuse the Apache shared number of concurrent builds
Will also add Slack notification to the #dev channel

+1 code blob would be ideally streamed right into the container in the future as well (from object store even). 

However this can be done already in terms of fetching the action code as WhiskActionMetadata for a run instead of WhiskAction (if the fetch cannot be eschewed entirely yet). This would allow the change to happen independent of the attachment work (incremental and semantic preserving change which later benefits by what should be a transparent change wrt attachments).
Wiki updated https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/wiki/Contributing:-Git-guidelines
This is already documented https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/docs/actions.md#creating-swift-actions
Closing as apigateway is already part of openwhisk.yml and it requires the routmgmt
PG2/2842 passed.  LGTM
Yeah, it's time to rebase.  Feel's like we are getting close, though.
FYI, I've done that for you in this [PR](https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/2413) that you rejected probably because of other incompatible PR with Zipkin-specific tracing

@rabbah we have the release repo. which serves that purpose incubator-openwhisk-release which is patterned after ones in Cordova and Spark.  I am not sure what a mega repo. would look like as we are not producing binaries yet., but eventually all binaries will be copied and submitted to the Apache artifactory; Vincent has documented (in repo. and "dev" list by reference) and demonstrated what the possible staged release future looks like on the last 2 Interchange calls and is on the agenda to continue to do so to provide updates.
@chetanmeh @rabbah If we are strictly talking about dependency graphs we can make that part of the release process along with tooling/utilities within incubator-openwhisk-utilities as well.

I think we are discussing two different things. A release is a cut after changes are committed. This issue and my comment above is about being able to develop across repos and committing new patches which then make it into a new release. 

Are we discussing the same things?

@rabbah it seems there is overlap, as the "checkout" tooling is being developed as part of the release repo. with manually identified components that are tied together by versioned functionality.  This would eventually include plug-ins for various providers.  Just do not want to re-invent the wheel and use different tools//methods where there is overlap.  Also, most developers will start from a known/tested base (i.e., a release) which they can pull from the tag or use the JSON file used to compile the release (and eventually the matching binaries).

These same tools and automated processes could be leveraged for daily/nightly or even "on demand" builds as well.
